I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Cambodia faces significant challenges in its efforts to reduce poverty. 
The National Strategic Development Plan (NSDP) 2006–2010, the Government’s third national 5- 
year plan, translates the development vision of the Rectangular Strategy for Growth, Employment, 
Equity,  and  Efficiency  (2003–2008)  and  reflects  the  Government’s  clear  poverty  focus.  The 
Rectangular Strategy had identified the need for capacity building for public financial management 
(PFM) as key to achieving long-term poverty reduction and had regarded governance as the most 
important precondition for economic development in Cambodia. The Government requested Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  grant  assistance  to  strengthen  PFM  in  the  line  ministries  that  are 
supporting rural development by assessing the ongoing PFM reforms in those ministries so as to 
identify areas of strategic focus for consolidating the current reforms and to prepare the groundwork 
for future reforms in a sequenced and prioritized framework.1 The National Audit Authority (NAA) of 
Cambodia also requested ADB to strengthen the state audit function in PFM reforms. 
 
2.  The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is part of ADB’s support to design the grant 
project for Strengthening of Public Financial Management for Rural Development Project (SPFMRD) 
for Cambodia and reflects ADB’s continuous support to PFM reforms.2 Conceptualization of this 
assistance was based on lessons learned from the implementation of ongoing projects and audit 
recommendations that underlined major weaknesses in internal control and procurement practices.3   
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Governance. Weak governance is a major obstacle that prevents Cambodia from achieving 
economic  growth,  inclusive  social  development,  and  poverty  reduction.  The  Government  has 
recognized corruption as a challenge and has given priority to governance reform in key policy 
documents, including the Rectangular Strategy and the NSDP 2006–2010. Cambodia joined the 
Asian Development Bank-Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (ADB-OECD) 
Anti-Corruption Initiative and Action Plan for Asia and the Pacific in 2003. Following ADB's adoption 
of  the  Second  Governance  and  Anticorruption  Action  Plan  (GACAP  II)  2005–2008  in  2006, 
Cambodia agreed in April 2007 to participate in regional technical assistance (RETA) 6385 on 
Governance and Capacity Development initiatives to implement GACAP II. 
 
4.  CSP and Good Governance. Good governance is at the core of ADB’s strategic focus. The 
country strategy and program (CSP) 2005–2009 and the CSP midterm review (2007–2009)4 for 
Cambodia  have  highlighted  the  need  for  good  governance  to  improve  responsiveness,  cost-
effectiveness, efficiency, and quality of public service delivery, especially to the poor. The CSP has 
identified the weak capacity for PFM, poor domestic resource mobilization effort, inefficient allocation 
of  public  expenditure  for  development  priorities  as  well  as  weak  linkages  among  policies,

5.  Public Financial Management Reform Program (PFMRP). The Government launched the 
PFMRP in December 2004 to address the problems. The PFMRP, supported by a multiagency trust 
fund, is a 10-year comprehensive reform program. The Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) is 
the lead agency responsible for its implementation. The PFMRP utilizes a platform approach to 
implement a package of measures for increasing levels (platform) of PFM competence over a 
manageable  timeframe  (Box  1).  The  program  seeks  to  make  the  budget  credible  as  a  policy 
instrument and focuses on measures like delivering resources reliably to budget managers; to 
improve  the  linkages  between  policy  priorities,  budget  planning,  and  implementation;  and  to 
integrate accountability and reporting of performance against the budget and program objectives, to 
ensure greater external transparency.  
Box 1: PFMRP Platform Approach 
 
Platform 1: Make the budget more credible in terms of timely and predictable delivery of funds 
(including  improving  the  comprehensiveness  of  the  budget;  strengthening  macro-fiscal  and 
revenue  forecasting,  and  streamlining  spending  processes).  Platform  2:  Implement  effective 
financial accountability. Platform 3: Achieve a fully affordable policy agenda through a policy-
budget linkage. Platform 4: Achieve effective program performance accountability. 
 
Source: PFM Reform Program, MEF, Royal Government of Cambodia. 2004. 
 
6.  At  a  retreat  in  April  2007  where  an  External  Advisory  Panel  (EAP)  report    assessing  
progress was discussed, the Government and development partners agreed that over the period 
2005–2006,  significant  progress  had  been  made  on  the  completion  of  Platform  1  (credible 
budgeting) by MEF, and MEF and the line ministries should expeditiously complete and deepen 
Platform 1 activities. At the same time, planning for Platform 2 should commence.6 The 2007 EAP 
assessment recognized the challenge of rolling out PFM reform to line ministries. The Government 
is aware that full implementation of PFM reforms across all ministries will be a long drawn-out 
process and developing the capacity of the line ministries is critical to the successful implementation 
of the PFMRP.  
 
7.   PFM for Rural Development. With poverty concentrated in agriculture and the rural sector, 
the Government’s strategy for enhancing growth, employment generation, and poverty reduction 
envisages the need for significant public expenditures for rural development with a corresponding 
need for adequate expenditure management and control mechanisms. Inroads into poverty require 
appropriate policies and institutions, including identification of poverty-reducing spending in the 
budget. In addition, parallel progress in strengthening links with PFM as a major crosscutting agenda. 
is needed. The institutional framework supporting rural development, therefore, requires sustained 
support in PFM mechanisms. No previous TA has addressed PFM reform specifically for the rural 
development sector. The ongoing PFMRP has a government-wide focus and has so far been 
concentrated  in  MEF,  and  the  rollout  to  line  ministries  has  not  been  satisfactory.  Given  this 
background, the TA will support a sector-wide PFM reform program in rural development that is 
consistent with CSP priorities and potential future support to the rural development sector. The 2003 
                                                 
5   ADB. 2007. Country Strategy and Program 2005–2009, Cambodia. Manila. 
6  The indicative activities and objectives of Platform 2 include (i) improved accountability lines―clarifying roles, functions, 
and responsibilities between levels of Government; (ii) improved accounting―initial consolidation of accounting data, 
and improved reconciliation procedures; (iii) improved reporting―interim improvements in reporting of performance 
against the budget; and (iv) strengthened capacity for both internal and external audit.

3
Integrated  Fiduciary  Assessment  and  Public  Expenditure  Review  (IFAPER)  and  the  recent 
governance risk assessments of the Ministry of Rural Development (MRD) and the Ministry of Water 
Resources  and  Meteorology  (MOWRAM)  provide  a  detailed  diagnosis  of  the  key  governance 
constraints and underline the need for substantial improvements in the institutions, processes, and 
capabilities relating to PFM. The rollout of the PFMRP, in this context, will be a fundamental risk 
mitigation measure.  
 
8.  Institutional  Strengthening  and  Accountability.  Strengthening  the  institutions  of 
accountability facilitates good governance. The supreme audit institution (SAI) of a country is a 
critical  pillar  of  the  system  of  institutional  check  and  balance.  It  provides  credible,  verifiable, 
independent  information  and  institutional  safeguards  against  malfeasance  and  abuse  of  public 
money,  thus  facilitating  good  governance.  The  Government  has  made  major  progress  toward 
establishing accountability and oversight mechanisms. Previous support from ADB and aid agencies 
has (i) strengthened the Finance and Banking Commission (FBC) of the National Assembly, and (ii) 
set up NAA as the supreme audit institution in Cambodia, with a legal mandate conferred by the 
Audit Law in March 2000. The Audit Law also has provisions for the interface between NAA and 
internal audit agencies.7 A priority in Cambodia is to strengthen NAA, including its capacity to 
undertake a performance audit of social sector spending, rural development projects, public works, 
and  public  contracts,  within  the  framework  of  the  International  Organization  of  Supreme  Audit 
Institutions (INTOSAI) international standards. A well-organized independent audit system with a 
strong mandate and financial autonomy, and vested with explicit rights and obligations to report its 
audit findings and recommendations will contribute to greater transparency and accountability. The 
internal audit function in most line ministries is also underdeveloped, having received little or no 
external support, despite an internal audit subdecree. Internal audit capability therefore needs to be 
strengthened in MRD, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF), and MOWRAM and in 
its constituent administrative establishments in provinces and districts since an effective internal 
audit  establishment  strengthens  internal  control  processes,  provides  strong  assurance,  and 
minimizes risks.  
 
9.  The Government’s priority focus on rural development and its desire for ADB to lead in this 
area will require a strong institutional reform program for rural development in line ministries focused 
on PFM. The timing of the TA is therefore appropriate. The TA will support efforts in meeting the 
benchmarks in PFM essential to achieving efficiency in resource allocation in the rural development 
sector. The benefits will be manifested in improved service delivery to the rural population. Improved 
governance and more transparent and accountable management of public resources arising from 
the  project  will  provide  the  basis  for  higher  and  more  efficient  public  expenditures  in  rural 
development and greater poverty reduction.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be to strengthen PFM in the rural development sector as a basic 
building block for improving service delivery and eradicating poverty in Cambodia. The  outcome will 
be an agreed-upon design for a grant project, which will include (i) a road map for institutional 
development in three line ministries (MAFF, MRD, and MOWRAM); and (ii) a road map for the 
strengthening of NAA and its capacity to undertake a performance audit of social sector spending in

the field of rural development. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The initial 
poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will build on the framework of the ongoing PFM reform measures and will involve 
close aid coordination and alignment with the consolidated action plan of the PFMRP platform 
approach. The project design, resulting from institutional assessments and diagnostics, will draw 
upon lessons from existing analytical work and incorporate feedback from stakeholder consultations. 
The TA will identify a set of specific measures to implement the ongoing PFM reform program 
activities,  and  recommend  areas  of  support  for  MRD,  MAFF,  MOWRAM,  and  NAA  including 
organizational  and  capacity  development  components  critical  for  deepening  PFM  reforms.  In 
consultation with the Government, development partners, and NAA, the TA will assess the role of 
NAA under the SPFMRD as well as the need for further institutional strengthening to improve audit 
oversight, especially in the rural development sector. The TA will develop modalities for providing 
financial and technical support for the ensuing grant to the finance and internal audit departments of 
the three line ministries, provincial departments, and other relevant units, with a clear set of selection 
criteria and guidelines for project implementation. The TA will also assess the resource allocation for 
NAA’s participation in the grant project and will identify potential areas for broad-based participation 
of civil society organizations in the PFM reform process. 
 
12.  The TA will have three outputs. 
 
(i)  Institutional assessment and diagnostic review. The assessment and review will 
consist of (a) analysis of  progress in rolling out PFM reforms to the three line 
ministries  MRD,  MAFF;  and  MOWRAM;  (b)  identification  of  the  institutional 
constraints in implementing reform measures; and (c) a road map for consolidating 
reforms initiated in Platform I, and for undertaking future reforms in the context of 
decentralization and deconcentration reforms. A comparative study of the progress of 
internal audit functions within MEF, the three line ministries, and selected provincial 
departments and districts, detailing activities for the organizational development of 
internal audit functions will be undertaken. Based on these background inputs, a road 
map  detailing  a  wide  range  of  activities  will  be  prepared  to  assist  in  designing 
programs that will contribute to strengthened PFM and organizational development of 
internal audit functions. These efforts will also include consensus-building seminars. 
 
(ii)  Capacity development and training. A comprehensive training needs analysis (TNA) 
will be undertaken to recommend corresponding capacity building measures in the 
three line ministries, selected provincial departments and districts, and NAA. TNA 
recommendations will build into a detailed training plan that will cover (a) training for 
relevant PFM issues under platforms 1 and 2, with emphasis on budget planning, 
program budgeting and budget execution; (b) specialized training for organizational 
and behavioral improvements; (c) change management; and (d) internal audit. During 
the design of the TA outcome, the training plan will be presented to a wide range of 
stakeholders through open seminars and workshops for defining the overall vision 
and implementation strategy of the SPFMRD. 
 
(iii)  Effectiveness of NAA and internal audit interface. The road map for institutional 
strengthening of NAA, including the capacity for performance audit of social sector 
spending and rural development projects, will be prepared. The road map will build on 
NAA’s Strategic Development Plan 2007–2011 and will include pilot audit of selected

5
projects. The TA will initiate the preparatory work to determine the terms of reference 
and costs for building a network of internal audit institutions and NAA for an improved 
interface between external audit and heads of internal audit departments. Thus the 
coordination mechanism will be strengthened.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $560,000.00 equivalent. The amount of $475,000.00 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund (JSF), funded by the Government of 
Japan.  The Government’s contribution to the TA will be in kind and will cover items of expenditure 
that are estimated at $85,000 equivalent. Appendix 3 presents the cost estimates and financing plan. 
The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  MEF will be the Executing Agency for the TA. MRD, MOWRAM, MAFF, and NAA will be the 
implementing agencies. The ADB project team, in coordination with the Cambodia Resident Mission, 
will coordinate implementation with all stakeholders, and development partners. In addition, the PFM 
Reform Committee, chaired by the Secretary of State, MEF, who concurrently chairs the Public 
Financial Management Technical Working Group, will function as the TA steering committee to 
provide guidance and will monitor TA progress.8  
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 9 months from December 2007 to August 2008, 
and will require three international consultants with skills in public financial management (6 person-
months),  institutional  development  (3.5  person-months),  and  state  audit  and  internal  audit (3.5 
person-months).  In  addition,  three national  consultants in  the  field of  audit  (5  person-months), 
budget (8 person-months), and capacity development (5 person-months) will provide support. Given 
the variety of the skills and experiences required and the intermittent nature of the assignments, all 
the consultants will be hired as individuals by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for the consultancy 
services, as well as the reporting requirements relating to the TA output are in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $475,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Cambodia for Preparing the Strengthening of Public Financial Management for Rural 
Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
8  Representatives from NAA and the Ministry of National Assembly-Senate Relation and Inspection (MONASRI) will be 
invited to meetings of the PFM Reform Committee.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 
With a low per capita income, Cambodia is one of the poorest countries of the world. Income poverty is 
high. Inequalities are deep-seated, the urban rural poverty divide is marked, and growth is non-inclusive. A 
World Bank Poverty Assessment in 2006 (Cambodia: Halving Poverty by 2015) cited the growing incidence 
of rural poverty despite a marked decline in the poverty level during the period 1994–2004. The study 
further showed that the prospect of growth in rural Cambodia, home to almost 91% of the poor and 
extremely deprived, is a challenge due to sluggish agricultural growth and lower labor productivity.  
 
This partly explains why Cambodia lags behind many developing countries on several human development 
indexes. It is ranked 129th out of 177 countries in the UN’s Human Development Report (2006). The human 
poverty index that looks beyond income deprivation similarly ranks Cambodia 73rd among 102 developing 
countries.  Cambodia faces daunting challenges in its efforts to achieve the Millennium Development Goals 
(MDGs), and may not be on track in many critical areas of food security, poverty reduction, and sustainable 
social and economic development.  
 
To enable Cambodia to meet its target under MDG 8, which calls for further development of an “open, rule-
based, non-discriminatory trading and financial system,” achieving progress in the crosscutting agenda of 
public financial management (PFM) would support progress in the sector by enhancing the effectiveness of 
public expenditures and improve sector efficiency and accountability. Robust PFM mechanisms will improve 
allocative efficiency and the investment climate. The impact of the project preparatory technical assistance 
(TA) on economic growth would be significant as good PFM practices promote pro-poor growth by directing 
public expenditure spending to the rural development sector.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
As suggested above, reform measures supported by this TA do not have a direct impact on poverty. No 
direct social impacts are, therefore, expected from the project. On the other hand, indirect social impacts 
are significant, manifested in improvements in the quality and quantity of public services and improved 
governance due to more transparent and accountable management of public resources. No adverse impact 
requiring mitigating measures was therefore identified.

D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
The envisaged TA design indicates that there will be no negative impact on women. The PFM outcome 
would  promote  inclusive  growth,  and  would  identify  gender-responsive  policy  changes,  based  on 
assessment and feedback during the TA implementation process.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of six individual consultants (three international and three national) will be hired 
to  provide  advice  and  technical  assistance.  An  estimated  31  person-months  of  consulting 
services (13 international and 18 national) will be required.  
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Public Financial Management Specialist and Team Leader (6 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
2.  The public financial management specialist and team leader will possess a successful 
track record in providing consulting services in public financial management (PFM), especially in 
developing countries  and  transitional  economies  in  the  region.  The specialist  will  have  an 
advanced university degree (master’s or the equivalent) preferably in business administration, 
economics,  finance,  or  a  relevant  combination  of  academic  qualifications  and  extensive 
experience in areas such as budgeting, or other directly related PFM areas. A minimum of 15 
years of progressively responsible experience in budgeting and financial management systems 
will be necessary. The specialist will possess competencies in the Public Expenditure and 
Financial Accountability (PEFA) program framework for improving PFM. Skills and experience 
specifically being sought include those involved in institutional change, project design, project 
monitoring and evaluation, logical framework analysis, assessing institutional accountability, and 
report  production.  As  team  leader,  the  specialist  will  possess  effective  interpersonal  and 
communication  skills  and  be  a  proficient  writer.  Previous  work  experience  in Cambodia  is 
desirable. The team leader will be responsible for all activities under the project preparatory 
technical  assistance  (TA),  including  coordinating  the  output  of  the  other  international  and 
national consultants and timely delivery of all activities. He/she will be required to adhere to the 
reporting requirements (TA inception report, a midterm report, a draft final report, and a final 
report) as set forth in the design and monitoring framework. Each report will be discussed in a 
tripartite  meeting  between  the  Government,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  and  the 
consultants. More specifically, the team leader will undertake the following tasks.  
 
(i)  Assess the status of the ongoing PFM reform program of the Government of 
Cambodia and identify institutional development measures needed including a 
range  of  training  and  capacity  development  activities  to  accomplish  the  key 
objectives of the program in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries 
(MAFF); Ministry of Rural Development (MRD); Ministry of Water Resources and 
Meteorology (MOWRAM); and National Audit Authority (NAA).1  
(ii)   Provide  analytical  inputs  and  assist  in  formulating  a  project  design  for 
strengthening  financial  management  in  line  ministries  dealing  with  rural 
development  (MRD,  MAFF,  and  MOWRAM),  including  a  road  map  for 
strengthening  NAA to improve its operational effectiveness.  
(iii)  Undertake diagnostic studies on the systemic strengths and weaknesses of the 
targeted ministries; identify lessons learned and build on them and on good 
practices from existing works. 
(iv)  Assist  in  project  description,  project  implementation  and  partnership 
arrangements, and monitoring and evaluation of outcomes.  
                                                 
1  For details refer to the Government’s (i) Ministry of Economy and Finance. 2004. Public Financial Managements 
Reform Program, Strengthening Governance Through Enhanced Public Financial Management. Phnom Penh 
(December); (ii) Ministry of Economy and Finance, Public Financial Management Reform Program, 2007. External 
Advisory Panel Report. Phnom Penh (20 April).

12       Appendix 4 
 
(v)  Build  consensus  to  identify  project  development  objectives,  key  indicators, 
project  outputs  that  strengthen  government  leadership  and  participation,  and 
provide for rigorous and consistent monitoring. 
(vi)  Assess  risks  for  the  three  ministries  following  ADB’s  Anticorruption  and 
Governance Action Plan – II and design a risk mitigation strategy for the three. 
(vii)  Provide inputs for preparing the design and monitoring framework (DMF) as  part 
of the project design, based on ADB’s Guidelines for Preparing a Design and 
Monitoring  Framework  (July  2007,  second  edition).  This  task  will  include 
providing  inputs  for  the  design  summary,  performance  targets/indicators/data 
sources/reporting  mechanisms,  assumptions/risks.  The  impact,  outcome,  and 
outputs, and activities with milestones relating to the project and inputs required 
for achieving those will be based on the DMF approach. The analytical and 
planning process and the design of the DMF matrix will follow ADB’s problem 
tree approach. 
(viii)  Identify a set of measures required to roll out ongoing PFM reform measures in 
the three ministries MAFF, MRD, and MOWRAM, including measures necessary 
to implement the road map for their institutional development. 
(ix)  Identify a set of measures around the good practices in budgeting and PFM in 
the context of implementing affordable pro-poor policies.2 
(x)  Identify a set of measures for strengthening NAA, including  its capacity for 
performance audit of social sector projects (audit of rural development projects, 
audit of public works, audit of public contracts), based on the respective outputs 
of the international institutional development specialist  and the international audit 
specialist. 
(xi)  Assist in developing a modality for providing financial and technical support from 
the ensuing grant to the selected line ministries, the finance and internal audit 
departments  of  the  three  ministries,  and  selected  provincial  departments, 
consistent with ADB’s operational guidelines. There should be a clear set of 
selection criteria and guidelines for undertaking activities that are considered 
direct costs and not funded by the Government during project implementation. 
The specialist will also assess the resource allocation for NAA’s participation in 
the project. 
(xii)  Evaluate the potential impact of the future organic law (decentralization and 
deconcentration  framework)  on  the  PFM  reform  process  and  on  the  fiscal 
relationship between the line ministries and the provincial departments under the 
three ministries.  
(xiii)  Assess the financial management capacity of the Executing Agency (Ministry of 
Economy and Finance [MEF]) and the implementing agencies (MAFF, MRD, 
MOWRAM,  and  NAA)  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  financial  management  and 
analysis of projects guidelines.3 
(xiv)  Produce a comprehensive report (TA final report) incorporating analytical results, 
based on tasks (i) to (xiii) above, in addition to the results of the outputs of the 
international  institutional  development  specialist  and  the  international  audit 
specialist.  
(xv)  Hold workshops and other meetings with stakeholders, including relevant civil 
society organizations to ensure effective dissemination and consensus-building.

http://go.worldbank.org/3I8LYLXO80 
3  ADB. 2005. Financial Management and Analysis of Project Guidelines. Manila.

Appendix 4       1 3
(xvi)  Perform any other tasks required in designing the project, including assisting 
ADB missions, to help achieve the objectives and goals of the TA within the 
approved budget.  
 
2.  Institutional Development Specialist (3.5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
3.  The  institutional  development  specialist  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  public 
administration, social sciences, economics, finance, and/or a closely related discipline. The 
specialist will have at least 10 years of progressively responsible experience in managing 
development assistance programs or similar projects in the field of organizational development, 
capacity building, and training, especially in developing countries and transitional economies in 
the region. Previous experience in administration, finance, and audit will be an asset. The 
specialist will (i) have  expertise and proven ability to advise on capacity building and training 
and effective writing and presentation skills; (ii)  be knowledgeable in preparing a framework for 
institutional development and organizational strengthening and will apply institutional processes 
such as facilitation skills, process tools, stakeholder analysis tools, institutional analysis tools, 
internal organization analysis tools, strategy and planning tools, etc.; (iii)  have progressively 
responsible experience in using tools for assessing institutional capacity, either at the national 
or  subnational  level;  (iv)  have  demonstrated  experience  with  participatory  approaches  that 
strengthen country ownership and the leadership of the executing agency;   (v) be flexible to 
adjust to the different approaches of the aid community; and (vi) be acquainted with methods of 
adopting  inclusive  approaches  for  a  variety  of  stakeholders.  Previous  work  experience  in 
Cambodia will be an advantage. More specifically, the specialist will undertake the following 
tasks.  
 
(i)  Carry out a comprehensive review of the organizational framework of MAFF, 
MRD, and MOWRAM; assess the strengths and weaknesses of their capacity 
and skills mix for implementing ongoing PFM reforms.  
(ii)  Do a comprehensive training needs analysis (TNA) to address critical gaps in 
core capacity for focused action across the targeted line ministries and selected 
provincial departments in the area of PFM and internal audit. The TNA would 
also include the capacity building and training needs on PFM issues of lawyers in 
the executing and implementing agencies. 
(iii)  Carry out functional reviews of the three line ministries to establish clarity of roles 
and commensurate responsibilities and identify measures for organizational and 
administrative  restructuring  to  improve  coordination,  information  flows,  and 
communications for efficient performance outcome.  
(iv)  On the basis of the TNA outcome, formulate a detailed capacity building and 
training  plan  on  crosscutting  PFM  issues,  with  strong  emphasis  on  budget 
planning, budget execution, accounting and reporting, internal audit functions in 
the targeted line ministries, in coordination with MEF, line ministries, ADB, and 
within the ongoing PFM reform program of the Government. The training will also 
cover designing and implementing a module on managing change. 
(v)  Design, with the team leader and international audit specialist, capacity and skills 
improvement  indicators  to  provide  a  starting  point  in  tracking  capacity 
improvements. 
(vi)  Regularly prepare reports, incorporating analytical results, based on tasks (i) to 
(v) above to feed into the team leader’s various analytical and thematic reports. 
This task will contribute to the efforts to design targeted interventions for capacity 
development and training for rolling out PMF reform measures.

14       Appendix 4 
 
3.  Audit Specialist (3 .5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
4.  The  audit  specialist  will  have  an  advanced  university  degree  in  accounting,  audit, 
business administration, commerce,  or a related field; or professional accounting, auditing or 
related designation (CA, CPA, CIA, CISA, and CFE); and a minimum of 10 years experience in 
government  audit,  internal  audit  and  public  sector  institutions,  or  other  directly  relevant 
experience in implementing similar projects, preferably at the international level in a developing 
country or transitional economies in the region. The specialist will have (i) a broad knowledge of 
general auditing standards and practices; audit tools and techniques, and the assessment of 
management systems and practices, financial and internal controls, and utilization of resources; 
(ii) significant knowledge of special audit and investigation practices and techniques; and (iii) 
extensive working experience in designing and implementing capacity development and audit 
training programs for the national supreme audit institution in the region. He/she must be fully 
knowledgeable  in  internal  control  processes  and  internal  audit  functions.  Previous  work 
experience  in  Cambodia  will  be  an  advantage.  The  specialist  must  have  demonstrated 
competence in (i) elements of the PEFA framework, (ii) International Organization of Supreme 
Audit  Institutions  (INTOSAI)  Auditing  Standards,  (iii)  Asian  Organization  of  Supreme  Audit 
Institutions (ASOSAI) Performance Auditing Standards, and  (iv) Implementation Guidelines and 
International Standards for the Professional Practice of Internal Auditing issued by the Institute 
of  Internal  Auditors  (IIA).  Knowledge  of  International  Public  Sector  Accounting  Standards 
(IPSASs)  set  by  the  International  Federation  of  Accountants  (IFAC)  will  be  helpful.  The 
specialist will have excellent written English language skills. He/she will report to the team 
leader and will coordinate activities with relevant officials of NAA; MEF; the line ministries MAFF, 
MRD, and MOWRAM; and the German Agency for Technical Cooperation (GTZ) focal point 
within NAA in undertaking the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Assess NAA as the supreme audit institution, including its capacity to effectively 
undertake  a  performance  audit  of  social  sector  projects,  especially  rural 
development projects, public works, and public contracts.  
(ii)  Identify a set of concrete measures for capacity building and training for NAA 
staff  within  the  NAA  Strategic  Development  Plan  2007–2011  framework, 
following international best practices and standards. 
(iii)  During  TA  implementation,  assist  NAA  in  the  pilot  audit  of  selected  rural 
development projects along with the internal audit staff of MRD, MAFF, and 
MOWRAM.  
(iv)  In coordination with MEF and NAA, make an in-depth assessment of the current 
state  of  internal  audit  functions  within  MRD,  MAFF,  MOWRAM,  and  the 
provinces  for  implementing  the  internal  audit  subdecree,  including  an 
assessment of the scope of the legal mandate of the internal subdecree, the 
provinces’ effectiveness, independence, and  charter of responsibilities 
(v)  Identify  a  set  of  measures  necessary to  establish  an  effective  internal  audit 
function within the selected line ministries; and raise their awareness of the 
objectives of internal audit.  
(vi)  Recommend an appropriate organizational structure and position descriptions for 
the internal audit group; and prepare a detailed training plan to develop the 
capacity in internal audit procedures and methodology to feed into the global 
training plan formulated by the international institutional development specialist.  
(vii)  Recommend a timetable with a set of activities for developing specific internal 
audit  manuals  for  the  line  ministries,  consistent  with  government-wide 
procedures.

Appendix 4       1 5
(viii)  Design the elements of an annual internal audit plan for implementation with 
specific milestones to achieve effective internal audit. 
(ix)  Develop terms of reference, including cost estimates, to establish a network of 
the heads of internal audit departments of all ministries and NAA for an improved 
interface  between  state  audit  and  internal  audit  for  exchange  of  ideas, 
knowledge-sharing and best practices, in coordination with MEF (Internal Audit 
Department) and NAA.  
(x)  With  the  team  leader,  design  indicators  of  capacity  and  skills  improvement; 
arrange an initial training on internal audit issues for the three ministries and 
monitor them throughout TA implementation; and gather baseline data on staff 
skills and levels to provide a starting point in tracking capacity improvement.  
(xi)  Prepare regular reports incorporating analytical results based on tasks (i) to (x), 
to submit to the team leader for him/her to consolidate into the various reports for 
submission to ADB and the Government. 
 
B.  National Consultants  
5.  Three  national  experts/specialists  will  be  hired  for  18  person-months  to  assist  the 
international consultants and the international team leader. The audit specialist (5 person-
months) will (i) have some detailed background in PFM development and be well-acquainted 
with recent developments in PFM reforms in Cambodia, including the Government policy and 
procedures; (ii) be thoroughly conversant with audit laws, all relevant decrees and subdecrees 
establishing NAA and proving the legal framework for internal audit; (iii)  have a minimum of 6 
years experience in internal audit; (iv) have  an understanding and knowledge of audit and 
accountability issues in Cambodia; and (v) be proficient in English. The budget specialist (8 
person-months) will assist the team leader and should (i) have some background in finance, 
especially public sector financial management issues; (ii) have a university degree either in 
economics  or  public  finance;  (iii)  be  proficient  in  English;  and  (iv)  be  familiar  with  the 
government structure and the particular functions of MEF. The capacity development expert (5 
person-months)  must  have  (i)  some  experience  in  implementing  a  capacity  development 
program in Cambodia, preferably in the area of financial management; and a significant amount 
of facilitation and communication skills. The specialists will undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Assist the team leader and the international specialists in all aspects of their task 
within  the  terms  of  reference;  collect  and  analyze  information,  and  make  it 
available in English in an organized, readable form; conduct research on specific 
topics as required by the team leader and the international specialists. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops; help the team leader and the 
international  specialists  prepare  materials  for  them,  including  translations  of 
documents (if necessary) and interpretation of the discussions; and coordinate 
translation works to be contracted to others. 
(iii)  Perform other tasks that may be assigned by the international audit specialist 
and the team leader.
